paragraphs.text: NASA's Earth Science Division (ESD) has a long-standing commitment to the full and open sharing of all data with research and applications communities, private industry, academia, and the general public, as defined in the ESD Data and Information Guidance. For most ESD-funded researchers, the designated repository will be a NASA Distributed Active Archive Center (DAAC). NASA DAACs are managed by NASA's Earth Science Data and Information System (ESDIS) Project, part of NASA's Earth Science Data System (ESDS) Program.

The following documentation provides guidelines to assist with the publication of NASA Earth science at a DAAC. If you have additional questions, please contact us and an Earthdata Pub team member will respond promptly.

paragraphs.heading: Data Acceptance Guidelines
paragraphs.text: Data can be considered for publication at a DAAC if any of the following criteria are met:
list: Produced by scientists at NASA facilities
Resulting from NASA research program funding
Resulting from NASA Applied Science funding if aligned with Earth observation data
Strongly supporting NASA Earth observation data

paragraphs.text: All data published at DAACs must be formally assigned by NASA to the DAAC. For more information on this process, see the Data Accession Process section.

paragraphs.heading: Preparing for Data Publication
paragraphs.text: Before submitting a request through Earthdata Pub to publish your data, please:
list:
Review guidance on how to create data and metadata that aligns with NASA standards
  • Earth Science Data Standards, Requirements, and References
  • Data Product Development Guide for Data Producers
Create a sample data file and browse file (if applicable)

paragraphs.heading: Data Accession Process
paragraphs.text: All data archived and distributed at DAACs must be formally assigned by NASA to the DAAC. Data from NASA science missions and some NASA research programs, as well as community-produced data, are directly assigned to a DAAC by NASA ESDIS.
The NASA Data Accession process is initiated by submitting a Data Accession request in Earthdata Pub. During the process, an assessment of the following will be conducted:
list: The data product’s alignment with the Data Acceptance Guidelines
The alignment of data file contents and structure with NASA standards
The appropriate Level of Service and the DAAC resources necessary to achieve the Level of Service

paragraphs.text: During the assessment, you may be contacted for additional information or obtain feedback from a User Working Group, an external advisory group representing the DAAC’s scientific discipline. This information will be assessed for approval. The time required to assign your data product to a DAAC will vary, but it can take several weeks.
You will be notified of the result of your Data Accession Request. If approved, you can work with the DAAC to publish your data. If not approved, you will be advised of the reasons for the decision.

paragraphs.heading: Data Publication Process
paragraphs.text: The primary goal of the data publication process is to make your data Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, and Reusable (FAIR). The data publication process is a collaboration between you and a DAAC and is initiated by submitting the Data Publication request form in Earthdata Pub. Once your data product has been published, the DAAC will continue to provide support and on-going stewardship of your data product while it remains available to the public.
The table below summarizes the typical activities performed during and after the publication of your data product, as well as your role and the role of the DAAC in these activities.

paragraphs.icon_text: The activities you may be asked to perform could differ from what is shown here depending on the mission or project requirements, the data Level of Service, and DAAC-specific processes.

paragraphs.text: The length of time required to publish your data product will vary depending on the complexity, the volume of the data, and the designated Level of Service. The DAAC publishing your data product can provide a publication time estimate.
